caption: Table 1: Wireless GA tokenizer. We describe how the mesh parameterizing the 3D environment and the information about antennas and their links are represented as a sequence of geometric algebra tokens. The mathematical representation of G3,0,1 primitives like points or orientated planes is described in Appendix A.
description: This table describes how different types of data used in modeling wireless signal propagation, such as 3D environment geometry, antenna properties, and channel information, are tokenized using geometric algebra.  The tokenizer transforms various data types into a sequence of geometric algebra tokens, which can be processed by the Wi-GATr network.  The table lists the data type, its input parameterization, the tokenization scheme, and the resulting channels in the G3,0,1 embedding.

caption: Table 2: Signal prediction results. We show the mean absolute error on the received power in dBm (lower is better, best in bold). Top: In-distribution performance. Middle: Generalization under symmetry transformations. Bottom: Generalization to out-of-distribution settings. In almost all settings, Wi-GATr is the highest-fidelity surrogate model.
description: This table presents the mean absolute error (MAE) in dBm for received power prediction using different models (Wi-GATr, Transformer, SEGNN, PLVIT) on the Wi3R and WiPTR datasets.  It evaluates performance under various conditions: in-distribution data, data augmented with symmetry transformations (rotation, translation, permutation, reciprocity), and out-of-distribution (OOD) layouts. Lower MAE values indicate better performance.  Wi-GATr consistently demonstrates superior prediction accuracy across nearly all scenarios.

caption: Table 3: Probabilistic modelling results. We show variational upper bounds on the negative log likelihood for different conditional inference tasks (lower is better, best in bold).
description: This table presents the results of probabilistic modelling experiments, specifically focusing on three conditional inference tasks: signal prediction, receiver localization, and geometry reconstruction.  The results are shown for both canonicalized scenes (aligned to axes) and scenes with arbitrary rotations.  The table compares the performance of the Wi-GATr model to a transformer baseline, both with and without data augmentation.  Lower values indicate better performance.

caption: Table 2: Signal prediction results. We show the mean absolute error on the received power in dBm (lower is better, best in bold). Top: In-distribution performance. Middle: Generalization under symmetry transformations. Bottom: Generalization to out-of-distribution settings. In almost all settings, Wi-GATr is the highest-fidelity surrogate model.
description: The table presents a comparison of different models' performance on signal prediction tasks using two datasets, Wi3R and WiPTR. The results are divided into three sections: in-distribution performance, generalization under symmetry transformations, and generalization to out-of-distribution settings. The mean absolute error (MAE) in dBm is used as the evaluation metric.

caption: Table 2: Signal prediction results. We show the mean absolute error on the received power in dBm (lower is better, best in bold). Top: In-distribution performance. Middle: Generalization under symmetry transformations. Bottom: Generalization to out-of-distribution settings. In almost all settings, Wi-GATr is the highest-fidelity surrogate model.
description: This table presents the mean absolute error (MAE) in dBm for received power prediction using different models (Wi-GATr, Transformer, SEGNN, PLVIT) on the Wi3R and WiPTR datasets.  It evaluates performance under various conditions: in-distribution data, data augmented with symmetry transformations (rotation, translation, permutation, reciprocity), and out-of-distribution data (OOD layouts).  Lower MAE values indicate better prediction accuracy, with Wi-GATr generally showing superior performance.
